ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  Jay was incredibly helpful in class and was very accessible.
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  Chancellor, Jay
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  NA
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  Jay Chancellor
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  I interacted the most with Jonathan Harris. But Jay was helpful too.
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  Jay Chancellor

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  He was very helpful explaining the why of topics instead of just how to do them.
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  I didn't interact much with my TA but he was available during each class session to assist students as needed which was a great resource.
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  Jay was very helpful and responsive throughout the semester.
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  Very approachable.
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  Holding office hours during class time was not helpful.
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  Jay was a good TA, he was available for question and gave straightforward explanations.
Instructor: Jay P. Chancellor  Graded thoroughly, was accessible during class. Could have interacted with students more.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: NA

Jonathan was a fantastic professor. His dedication to his students' learning shows in the many office hours both in-person, and via Skype, phone, email, etc, he offered to students every week. I really appreciate his making an introductory course feel challenging (in a positive way). I feel that I have learnt a lot about statistics that I can now carry with me throughout my future professional career.

Jonathan RS sets up this class for multiple learning styles with video, in person class time, practical time, and is accessible personally more than any other professor. TFs were accessible, Jonathan Harris in particular.

I learned a lot in this course. Jonathan Reuning-Scherer is an excellent teacher, and his experience shows. He usually anticipates our questions and knows which concepts will be more or less difficult to understand. He often has multiple ways of explaining the same concept and if a student does not understand one explanation, he can quickly change gears and use a different example that demonstrates the concept in a different way. I like that he has found a series of datasets which are best for explaining each concept and is able to consistently refer to them.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I enjoyed the flipped class and liked doing everything on the computer along with the instructor.
Instructor enthusiasm!
Lots of hands-on activities which made theoretical material much more digestible. Jonathan was always available to assist students as necessary, which was very gracious of him.
All of the practice we had on the computer. How available Jonathan was for questions. The videos were awesome because you could pause him when he was going a million miles per hour.

The flipped version increased the amount of one-on-one time we had working both with the software and with Jonathan, which was very helpful. I appreciated the multi-faceted approaches to learning via video, in-class review/lectures, and homework. All this weekly exposure helped the information sink in so I was able to keep up with the learning curve.
Real examples and practice.

I really liked the videos. They are very clear and well put-together. I wish I could have a copy of them to refer to in the future--although I suppose the lecture notes will do. Jonathan's understanding of how people learn statistics allows him to create an accessible, logical flow for each video.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More in-class working through problems that are similar to the homework. While there were opportunities for this (which were good), sometimes the homework problems seemed to be a bit further afield than notes and lecture covered. Perhaps the burden is on us, the students, to explore more problems in the suggested textbooks. However, problems with solutions available similar to homework problems would have help my comprehension and overall grade.
I really like the lab component and would recommend that it be kept in some way in future iterations, even if the flipped version of the course is discontinued.

I think you could force us to come to your office hours if you cut out the time in beginning of class to answer questions. It's rarely useful to the whole class and the time could be better spent working on the computer.

Problem set length. Some of the problem sets took much longer than others. Perhaps a more standardized length would help students keep better track of how much time they need to dedicate to it since they are weekly assignments.
Maybe trying to relate the different tools leaner in the class (Tree diagram at the end) with some of the homework we had, by making a more explicit connection with the chart.
More hands on class time.
My only critique is that I wish there had been videos for the last few weeks--or maybe my mistake was not printing the notes to bring to class for the lectures.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: When there were difficult homework assignments issued, the TA sessions were often so busy it was difficult to get help in the time allotted. Much of the time, the TA had spent a good portion of time answering the very questions you were bringing before you got there. Perhaps a video run-through of FAQ for the homework assignments might help alleviate some of the pressure on the TAs that often answer the same questions over and over.
Yes - clear explanation of theory during lectures and the opportunity to apply right afterward during lab was great.
see above. keep videos.

Jonathan Harris was an amazing TA. He was always very helpful and never gave answers away too easily; rather, he would come up with other examples and work with you one-on-one until it finally clicked. I'm not sure I would have succeeded as much as I did in this course if it were not for his help. Thank you!
Lectures directly lined up with labs/Q and A.

I really like that we started each class by discussing any questions anyone might have about the material covered in the videos. I thought the homework was very effective at tying the concepts together, and I appreciate how accessible Jonathan is for any questions that may arise.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Good statistical foundation for research - wish I had taken it sooner.
I can finally read a journal article and get their data analysis (sometimes). Really changed the way I do science.
Adds to my quantitative skill set.
It was great!

It is critical that I not only learn statistics but also that I am able to proficiently use them and to think critically about the statistics used in scientific articles. This course has provided me with a solid foundation upon which I am eager to build my knowledge.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To analyze data for my MESc research.
I need it!!!!!!
I wanted to learn statistics.

My adviser expects me to perform statistical analyses on my data with minimal guidance. I took statistics as part of my undergraduate degree, but it has been over 10 years and the course I took was of low quality. I took this course because I needed a new start with statistics.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes - I wish we had more time to learn about nonlinear regression but it was a very good introduction.
This was the best class I took this semester. I am really happy to have met Jonathan and know he's here for us as a resource too.
Yes

Yes! I was astonished to find that the paltry explanations I had been given for statistical concepts during my undergraduate course work were actually backed up by clear, logical mathematical reasoning. Instead of bewildered and intimidated, I feel knowledgeable and reassured that there is a sensible explanation for any statistical concept.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was great being able to bounce ideas off of each other and learn from other students
NA
Advantages were that I didn't have to do all the writing on the final project.

The final group project was a nice culminating feature of the course. My group mates and I worked well together and although we ran into a lot of trouble with our data, it was a good learning experience.

The work group as a part of the final assignment was great because it allowed for creativity and knowledge sharing. The disadvantage was that it was during finals; I wish we had done this type of group work throughout the class- as part of the midterm perhaps. I felt like I learned more from this assignment than working on my own.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the course
Watch the video lectures before class and do all of the homework. The class is very manageable but you will get the most out of it if you are organized with your work.
Take the flipped course!
Take the flipped version if you can.

The class was great, my last stats class was 8 years ago so I was very rusty. The topics are extremely useful and you really find yourself using them all the time later one. Also Jonathan is the best, he is there to answer question even if you are working in something not related to the class and he really enjoys teaching, and makes stats enjoyable (+1)
Read the text books along with the videos. Take advantage of all the help- early and often. Keep up!
If you even a shadow of a doubt that your understanding of statistics may not quite cut the mustard--or if your last statistics course was years ago--you stand to gain a great deal from this course!
